references:
TableÂ 1 illustrates
the contribution of each individual loss component on LineMOD.
Note that supervision from both
visual and geometry domains
is vital for our self-supervised training.
Disabling either â„’mâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹ksubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘˜\mathcal{L}_{mask} or â„’gâ€‹eâ€‹oâ€‹msubscriptâ„’ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘œğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{geom} almost always leads to unstable training and divergence (the average recall is only 0.1%percent0.10.1\% and 6.4%percent6.46.4\% w.r.t.Â ADD(-S)).
The remaining three factors, measuring color similarity, have a comparably small impact. Concretely,
we drop by more than 2%percent22\% when disabling â„’mâ€‹sâ€‹-â€‹sâ€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹msubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ‘ -ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{ms\text{-}ssim}, and about 1%percent11\% referring to â„’aâ€‹bsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{ab} and â„’pâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹câ€‹eâ€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹uâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘™\mathcal{L}_{perceptual}. Nonetheless, we still achieve the overall best results when applying all loss terms together.
Most importantly, we can report a significant relative improvement of almost 50%percent5050\% from 40.1%percent40.140.1\% to 58.9%percent58.958.9\% leveraging the proposed self-supervision.
Moreover, except for the Duck object, all other objects undergo a strong enhancement in ADD(-S).
Noteworthy, we can almost halve the difference between training with and without real pose labels.

id_table_2.caption: Table 2: Results for LineMOD. Top: Qualitative results. We depict the 6D pose by overlaying the 3D bounding box onto the input image. Blue constitutes the ground truth pose, red and green show our results before and after self-supervision. None of the samples has been seen before. Bottom: Comparison with state-of-the-art. We present the results for the Average Recall(%) of ADD(-S) metric. Real Pose Labels refers to the 15% training split fromÂ [3] with pose labels. We use the same split for training, however, without employing labels.222The numbers of [61] and [40] are different as in their paper since they used average precision instead. The authors provided us with their results for average recall.

references:
In line with other works, we distinguish between training with and without real pose labels, i.e.Â making use of annotated real training data. Despite exploiting real data, we do not employ any pose labels and must, therefore, be classified as the latter. We want to highlight that our model can produce state-of-the-art results for training with and without labels. Referring to TableÂ 2, for training using only synthetic data, Self6Dâˆ’LBSelf6DLB\operatorname{Self6D-LB} reveals an average recall of 40.1%percent40.140.1\%, which is deliberately better than AAEÂ [52] with 31.4%percent31.431.4\% and on par with MHPÂ [38] and DPOD222The numbers of [61] and [40] are different as in their paper since they used average precision instead. The authors provided us with their results for average recall.Â [61]
reporting 38.8%percent38.838.8\% and 40.5%percent40.540.5\%. On the other hand, as for training with real pose labels, we are again on par with other recently published methods such as PVNetÂ [44] and CDPNÂ [30] reporting a mean average recall of 86.9%percent86.986.9\%.
Furthermore, our proposed self-supervision Self6DSelf6D\operatorname{Self6D} achieves an overall average recall of 58.9%percent58.958.9\%, which is more than 51%percent5151\% of relative improvement over all state-of-the-art methods using no real pose labels.
Except for Holep, Duck and Iron, we can report a significant increase. Objects with little variation in color and geometry can become difficult to optimize.
In addition, the 3D mesh of the Holep is rather different
compared with
the actual perceived object in the real images, which makes our visual alignment less meaningful.

references: Since our method is suitable for conducting synthetic to real domain adaptation, we assess transfer skills referring to the commonly used Cropped LineMOD scenario. We self-supervise the model with the real training set from Cropped LineMOD, and report the mean angle error on the real test set. As shown in Table 4, our synthetically trained model (Self6Dâˆ’LBSelf6DLB\operatorname{Self6D-LB}) slightly exceeds state-of-the-art methods as PixelDAÂ [2]. Self6DSelf6D\operatorname{Self6D} can successfully surpass the original model on the target domain, reducing the mean angle error from 19.8â€‹Â°19.8Â°19.8\degree to 15.8â€‹Â°15.8Â°15.8\degree.

references:
Since our self-supervision relies on high quality of the predicted masks from our synthetically trained model Self6Dâˆ’LBSelf6DLB\operatorname{Self6D-LB}, we present the detailed quantitative evaluation in TableÂ 6. Specifically, we calculated F1 score and IoU between the predicted masks and the ground-truth masks on LineMOD test set. We can see that the predicted masks are very accurate on almost all objects, with the average F1 score 89.63% and mIoU 90.38%.
Thus we can regard the predicted masks from Self6Dâˆ’LBSelf6DLB\operatorname{Self6D-LB} as a reliable self-supervision signal. Fig.Â 5 shows some qualitative examples for the predicted masks on LineMOD test set.

We first fully supervise Self6Dâˆ’LBSelf6DLB\operatorname{Self6D-LB} on a mixture of synthetic RGB images from YCB-Video and photorealistic renderings fromÂ \citeAtremblay2018fallingA.
We then self-supervise the model on 10% of the real RGB-D images for each of these 5 objects from the training set, however, without leveraging any 6D annotations (Self6DSelf6D\operatorname{Self6D}).
Since the first four objects exhibit rotational symmetries, we report the average recall for ADD-S for them. For the remaining object (i.e.Â 035_power_drill), we refer to ADD instead, as it does not possess rotational symmetries. In line with all other experiments, we can constitute that leveraging our self-supervision, we are able to significantly enhance the average recall w.r.t.Â ADD(-S) for each object (TableÂ 7).
